messages.0004be8f6b3629f0e708d1ec68ed0e10:
The default compute gateway firewall rules prevent all traffic from VMs from reaching the internet. To allow your virtual machines to reach the internet, you need to create a compute gateway firewall rule to allow outbound traffic on the logical network that your VM is connected to.

  1. Go to the Network tab for the SDDC.
  2. Under either Compute Gateway, expand the Firewall Rules section.
  3. Click Add Rule.
  4. Enter the rule parameters:
    • Rule Name: Enter a name for the rule.
    • Action: Select Allow.
    • Source: Enter the CIDR block IP address range assigned to the logical network for the VM.
    • Destination: Enter Any.
    • Service: Select Any (All Traffic).
messages.0bedef5eb3bf011102af4dde2ffd30f3: Features released in preview have been released to gather feedback. These features are marked with a Preview icon in the UI. These features might not be available to all customers or in all AWS regions. We cannot guarantee that features that are in "Preview" will become available within any particular time frame or at all. Make your purchase decisions only on the basis of features that are available.
messages.0f673b9345c9b2d37731c1bc20ea21d7:
You can remove a host as long as you remain above the minimum of 3 hosts in an SDDC cluster:

  1. Go to the Summary tab for your SDDC.
  2. Select Actions > Remove Hosts.
  3. Select the number of hosts to remove.
  4. Select I understand that this action cannot be undone.
  5. Click Remove.

It might take up to a few hours to resize the SDDC. While the hosts are being removed, your workloads and vCenter Server continue to run as normal, but you are not able to start additional add or remove host actions.
messages.1041670326db849c3331e1879416f57a:
If you are a member of more than one organization, you can set a default organization. This organization will be the one displayed when you log in.

  1. From the VMC Console dashboard, click your username and organization in the tool bar.
  2. Click Set Default Organization and select the organization you want as the default.
messages.147a7e2ad24bb56ec548c1540fcb6fe8:
From the Dashboard, you can:

  • View all of the SDDCs created in the current organization. You can click on an individual SDDC to open vCenter Server, view details, or delete the SDDC.
  • Monitor the progress of ongoing SDDC deployments.
  • Click Create SDDC to create a new SDDC.
  • Click Invite Users to invite other users to your organization.
  • Click your username at the top right to switch organizations (if you are a member of multiple organizations), view your profile, generate an OAuth Token, and set your default organization.
messages.1611103ba0feffd85e1a9f1d8c264a91:
Configure DNS to allow machines in your SDDC to resolve fully-qualified domain names (FQDNs) to IP addresses. When configuring DNS, do not configure one public DNS server and one private (on-premises) DNS server. Doing so leads to unpredictable DNS results.

  1. On the Network tab for your SDDC, expand DNS under either Management Gateway or Compute Gateway.
  2. Click Edit.
  3. Enter IP addresses for DNS Server 1 and (optionally) DNS Server 2.
  4. If you are configuring DNS for the management gateway, select how the fully-qualified domain name (FQDN) for vCenter Server should be resolved.
    • If you access vCenter Server from the internet, select Public IP.
    • If you have configured a VPN and use the VPN to access vCenter Server, select Private IP.
  5. If you are configuring DNS for the compute gateway, and you have configured private DNS servers, ensure that you have configured your VPN to allow DNS requests over the compute gateway VPN by selecting cgw-dns-network as one of the local networks for VPN. See "How do I set up an IPsec VPN connection to the Compute Gateway?" for more information.
messages.1e7fa90bb4da44fd3a9411ebf9db3435:
Unless otherwise indicated, these settings cannot be edited in the VMC Console. If you choose other values for the editable settings, ensure that your on-premises gateway is set to match what you have set in the VMC Console.

Phase 1 Internet Key Exchange (IKE) Settings

  • Protocol: IKEv1
  • ISAKMP mode: Main mode (Disable aggressive mode)
  • ISAKMP/IKE SA lifetime: 28800 seconds (8 hours)
  • Encryption (editable): AED-256
  • Hashing: SHA-1
  • Diffie Hellman (editable): DH Group 2
  • IPsec Mode: Tunnel
  • IKE Authentication: Pre-shared Key

Phase 2 Settings

  • Encryption (editable): AES-256
  • Hashing: SHA-1
  • Tunnel Mode: Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP) Tunnel Mode
  • Diffie Hellman (editable): DH Group 2
  • SA lifetime: 3600 seconds (1 hour)
  • Perfect forward secrecy (PFS): Enabled
messages.2283807a9964ef305873059103b3049b: The pre-shared key is used by the two ends of the management gateway VPN tunnel to authenticate with each other, so both the SDDC gateway and your on-premises gateway must use the same key. The key has a maximum length of 128 characters. Treat the pre-shared key as you would a password: keep it confidential, and don't use email or other insecure methods to communicate the key to others.
messages.2c1ba2f7d865746fd731ed552a7f0b2e:
Before you can access the vSphere Client, you must configure a VPN connection or firewall rule to permit access to vCenter Server. See Set Management Gateway Firewall Rules.

Click the hyperlink under vSphere Client (HTML5) and use the username and password displayed on the Connection Info page to log in.
messages.30b59ac2bbc24fc5bbec7cbb1e9a495f:
You can configure a public virtual interface to access AWS public services such as S3 to travel over the Direct Connect connection. You can also establish the management and compute gateway VPN tunnels over the Direct Connect public virtual interface.

Before you create a public virtual interface, ensure that you meet the Prerequisites for Virtual Interfaces.

  1. Log in to the AWS Console.
  2. Click Direct Connect and then click Virtual Interfaces.
  3. Click Create Virtual Interface.
  4. Select Public to create a public virtual interface, and then select My AWS Account as the virtual interface owner.

After the public virtual interface is created, configure your management and compute gateway IPsec VPNs so that the remote gateway IP and remote networks correspond to the device that terminates your Direct Connect connection in your on-premises data center.
messages.368b83feade4e30006d029979ca09467: If you have the ability to add hosts, and your SDDC isn't at its maximum number of hosts, you can add a host to increase the available storage capacity. Otherwise, shut down workloads or migrate them off of your SDDC.
messages.371bacda2d54ffb6283b3c1ba319749f:
During the SDDC creation, you connect your SDDC to an AWS account, and select a VPC and subnet within that account. Using a CloudFormation template, VMware Cloud™ on AWS creates an Elastic Network Interface (ENI), allowing your SDDC and services in the Amazon VPC and subnet in your AWS account to communicate without needing to route traffic through the internet gateway. You can only connect an SDDC to a single Amazon VPC.

You can view details of your connected Amazon VPC, such as the account ID, VPC ID, and subnet by clicking Connected Amazon VPC on the Networking tab.
messages.399fb082e659bd059c329d47187b2c9b:
Before you can access the vSphere Client, you must configure either a VPN connection or a firewall rule to permit access to vCenter Server. See Set Management Gateway Firewall Rules.

Click the hyperlink under vSphere Client (HTML5) and use the username and password displayed on the Connection Info page to log in.
messages.48964c31fdfaa31e73dd1678ae622e6d:
You can create a VPN connection from the compute gateway of your SDDC to an on-premises compute network.

  1. On the Networking tab for your SDDC, complete the Compute Gateway VPN configuration.
    • VPN Name: Enter a name for the VPN.
    • Remote Gateway Public IP: Enter the IP address of your on-premises gateway.
    • Remote Gateway Private IP: If your on-premises gateway is behind NAT, enter the private IP address of your on-premises gateway.
    • Remote Networks: Enter the address of your on-premises compute networks.
    • Local Gateway IP: Displays the IP address of the SDDC compute gateway. This is not an editable field.
    • Local Network: Select the logical network to connect to using this VPN. If the logical network uses DHCP and you have configured an on-premises DNS server, also select the cgw-dns-network to allow DNS requests to travel over the VPN.
    • Encryption: Select AES-256.
    • Perfect Forward Secrecy: Select Enabled.
    • Diffie Hellman: Select a Diffie Hellman group. This must match with what is configured for your on-premises gateway.
    • Pre-Shared Key: Enter a key string with a maximum length of 128 characters.
  2. Configure the on-premises side of the VPN tunnel using the recommended cryptography settings. See the VMware Cloud on AWS Getting Started Guide for more information on configuring specific gateway devices.

You can verify that the VPN tunnel is successfully connected by looking at the VPN status on the Networking tab.
messages.48a5b54af2520255a60f1aeb8acc32fc:
You can create a VPN connection from the compute gateway of your SDDC to an on-premises compute network.

  1. On the Networking tab for your SDDC, complete the Compute Gateway VPN configuration.
    • VPN Name: Enter a name for the VPN.
    • Remote Gateway Public IP: Enter the IP address of your on-premises gateway.
    • Remote Gateway Private IP: If your on-premises gateway is behind NAT, enter the private IP address of your on-premises gateway.
    • Remote Networks: Enter the address of your on-premises compute networks.
    • Local Gateway IP: Displays the IP address of the SDDC compute gateway. This is not an editable field.
    • Local Network: Select the logical network to connect to using this VPN. If the logical network uses DHCP and you have configured an on-premises DNS server, also select the cgw-dns-network to allow DNS requests to travel over the VPN.
    • Encryption: Select AES-256.
    • Perfect Forward Secrecy: Select Enabled.
    • Diffie Hellman: Select a Diffie Hellman group. This must match with what is configured for your on-premises gateway.
    • Pre-Shared Key: Enter a key string with a maximum length of 128 characters.
  2. Configure the on-premises side of the VPN tunnel using the recommended cryptography settings. See the VMware Cloud on AWS Getting Started Guide for more information on configuring specific gateway devices.

You can verify that the VPN tunnel is successfully connected by looking at the VPN status on the Networking page.
messages.4b1343d42dce723ba29e55b781b412ac:
A private virtual interface allows ESXi management traffic and vMotion traffic to flow over the Direct Connect connection between your on-premises environment and your SDDC.

Before you create a private virtual interface, ensure that you meet the Prerequisites for Virtual Interfaces.

  1. Determine the account ID for your VMC AWS account. This is displayed under the Direct Connect section of the Networking tab of your SDDC.
  2. Log in to the AWS Console.
  3. Click Direct Connect adn then click Virtual Interfaces.
  4. Click Create Virtual Interface.
  5. Select Private to create a private virtual interface. Select Another AWS Account as the account owner, and enter the account ID of your VMC AWS account.
  6. Log in to VMC Console and navigate to the Networking tab of your SDDC.
  7. Under Direct Connect, expand Virtual Interfaces and click Attach next to the virtual interface you created.
  8. Select I understand that I will be responsible for data transfer charges incurred for the interface and click Accept Virtual Interface.
  9. If you have an IPsec VPN configured, update your VPN settings.
    1. In the VMC Console, refresh the management IPsec VPN settings. The network topology diagram shows the management appliance subnet address in the Appliance Subnet field.
    2. Update the remote network setting in your on-premises gateway to use the management appliance subnet address.
messages.4f87a32661f5b7d16a44c3302de7d26f:
You can't change the values specified for the management network after the SDDC has been created. Consider the following when you choose these values:

  • The only supported sizes for the CIDR block range are /23, /20, and /16.
  • If you plan to connect your SDDC to an on-premises data center, the IP addresses you choose for your SDDC must be different from those in your on-premises data center, to avoid IP address conflicts.
  • The maximum number of hosts your SDDC can contain depends on the size of the CIDR block you specify. If the CIDR block is specified in the form XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX/YY, then the maximum number of hosts the SDDC can contain will be (2 ^(27 - YY)) - 3. For example, if you specify the CIDR block 192.0.2.0/23, the maximum number of hosts is (2 ^(27 - 24)) - 3, or 13.

Note: Although the number of host IP addresses available in a /16 CIDR block is 2045, the maximimum number of hosts in the SDDC is limited by other factors to 160.
messages.504c453076570eee108f676037cdb3fd:
To invite another user, you need to be an Organization Owner.

  1. From the VMC Console dashboard, click Invite Users.
  2. Enter the email addresses for the users you want to invite.
  3. Select the role for the users you are inviting. You can select Organization Owner or Organization Member.
  4. Click Add.

The users you invite will receive an email with a link and additional instructions allowing them to sign up for VMware Cloud on AWS.
messages.512168942276546150ab4591791d2c97:
You can create a VPN connection from the management gateway of your SDDC to your on-premises management network.

  1. On the Networking tab for your SDDC, complete either the Management Gateway VPN configuration.
    • VPN Name: Enter a name for the VPN.
    • Remote Gateway Public IP: Enter the public IP address of your on-premises gateway.
    • Remote Gateway Private IP: If your on-premises gateway is behind NAT, enter the private IP address of your on-premises gateway.
    • Remote Networks: Enter the address of your on-premises management networks.
    • Local Gateway IP: Displays the IP address of the SDDC management gateway. This is not an editable field.
    • Local Network: Displays the CIDR block of the management subnet for the management gateway. This is not an editable field.

    • Perfect Forward Secrecy: Select Enabled.

    • Pre-Shared Key: Enter a key string with a maximum length of 128 characters.
  2. Configure the on-premises side of the VPN tunnel using the recommended cryptography settings. See the VMware Cloud on AWS Getting Started Guide for more information on configuring specific gateway devices.

You can verify that the VPN tunnel is successfully connected by looking at the VPN status on the Networking page.
messages.51e82d2f893994cad4a0435b6704fa8a:
You must create several firewall rules to enable management and replication traffic, and the VMware Site Recovery service.

To enable management and API access:

  1. Allow inbound service HTTPS (TCP 433) to vCenter
  2. Allow inbound service SRM Server Management (TCP 9086) to Site Recovery Manager
  3. Allow inbound service VR Server Management (TCP 8043) to vSphere Replication
  4. Allow outbound service Any (All Traffic) from vCenter, Site Recovery Manager, and vSphere Replication

To enable replication traffic:

  1. Allow inbound service VM Replication (TCP 31031, 44046) to vSphere Replication
  2. Allow outbound service Any (All Traffic) from ESXi Management Only

To enable access to the Site Recovery console

  1. Allow inbound HTTPS (TCP 443) to vSphere Replication
messages.52939d0bf7f6e015fc43b762e1fe79b0: You can deploy additional hosts later if your SDDC contains fewer hosts than the maximum allocated to your organization.
messages.52b8f73acf9935a10aed190f248e5a6c:
To remove another user from an organization, you need to be an Organization Owner.

  1. From the VMC Console dashboard, click the services icon at the top right of the window, and select Identity and Access Management.
  2. Select the user or users you want to remove.
  3. Click Remove Users.
  4. Click Remove to confirm the removal.

The user is removed from the organization and will no longer be able to access the organization's resources.
messages.5ba0833e46158bb895f9a8776f02fb99: VMware Site Recovery Manager allows you to perform automatic disaster recovery of virtual machines from your on-prem datacenter to your SDDC in the cloud.
messages.5c4cd561f50297e3eb2c5783b9405139:
During the SDDC creation, you connect your SDDC to an AWS account, and select a VPC and subnet within that account. Using a CloudFormation template, VMware Cloud™ on AWS creates an Elastic Network Interface (ENI), allowing your SDDC and services in the Amazon VPC to communicate without needing to route traffic through the internet gateway. You can only connect an SDDC to a single Amazon VPC.

Ensure that you have an AWS account and suitable VPC before you create an SDDC. Create the VPC in the same region that you intend to use for your SDDC, and create a subnet with at least 64 IP addresses (a /27 CIDR block) in each availability zone (AZ) in your VPC.

To create a new SDDC:

  1. From the Dashboard, click Create SDDC.
  2. Follow the steps to connect your AWS account, set SDDC properties, and select the subnet. See Deploy an SDDC from the VMC console for more details.

The status of the SDDC deployment is displayed on the Dashboard.
messages.6ced784d9c5e00071eff86b77b849f2e:
On the networking page, you can:

  • View a topology diagram showing the status of network connections to and from your SDDC.
  • Create firewall rules for the management and compute gateways.
  • Configure VPN settings for IPsec VPN connections between your SDDC and an on-premises data center.
  • Configure DNS settings for the management and compute gateways.
  • View logical networks. (To configure logical networks, use the vSphere Client.)
  • Configure inbound NAT for your compute gateway.
  • Create public IP addresses for your compute gateway.
  • View information about your connected Amazon VPC.
  • Attach AWS Direct Connect private virtual interfaces to your SDDC.
messages.7f1e7006f73bb6f25bf233669f10341a:
By default, the firewall for the compute gateway is set to deny all inbound and outbound traffic. Add additional firewall rules to allow traffic as needed.

  1. Go to the Network tab for the SDDC.
  2. Under either Compute Gateway, expand the Firewall Rules section.
  3. Click Add Rule.
  4. Enter the rule parameters:
    • Rule Name: Enter a name for the rule.
    • Action: Select Allow or Deny.
    • Source: Enter or select one of the following.
      • Select All Internet and VPN to apply the rule to all traffic from the Internet and VPN.
      • Select All Connected Amazon VPC to apply the rule to all traffic from the connected Amazon VPC.
      • Enter Any to apply the rule to traffic from all sources.
      • Enter one or more IP addresses or IP adress ranges, separated by commas to apply the rule to traffic from those specific IP addresses.
    • Destination: Enter or select one of the following.
      • Select All Internet and VPN to apply the rule to all traffic to the Internet and VPN.
      • Select All Connected Amazon VPC to apply the rule to all traffic to the connected Amazon VPC.
      • Enter Any to apply the rule to traffic to all sources.
      • Enter one or more IP addresses or IP adress ranges, separated by commas to apply the rule to traffic to those specific IP addresses.
    • Service:Select one of the following:
      • Any (All Traffic): The rule applies to all traffic.
      • A specific service: The rule applies to traffic from the selected service and port.
      • ICMP (All ICMP): The rule applies to all ICMP traffic
      • Custom TCP or Custom UDP: To define a custom service and port to apply the rule to.
    • Ports: If you selected a custom TCP or UDP service, enter the port number.

Firewall rules are applied in order from top to bottom. Use the up and down arrow icons to move firewall rules
messages.815b9b868cca3fed897e848acddbf460:
VMware Hybrid Cloud Extension (HCX) abstracts on-premises and cloud resources and presents them to workloads as a hybrid cloud. This allows workload mobility between your on-premises data center and cloud SDDC.

HCX is included as part of your VMC on AWS service. For additional information on installing and configuring HCX, see Hybrid Migration with HCX Checklist.
messages.8779212284284274601fb331ab4033a1:
Logical networks are displayed in the VMC Console, but you use the vSphere Client to create them.

  1. On the Connection Info tab for your SDDC, click the link under vSphere Client (HTML5) and log in with your vCenter Server credentials.
  2. Select Menu > Global Inventory Lists and select Logical Networks
  3. Click the add button.
  4. In the Name text field, enter a name for the logical network.
  5. In the CIDR Block text field, enter a CIDR block in xxx.xxx.xxx.0/YY format.

    Prefix length should be between 22 and 30, because your logical network must have no more than 1000 ports.

  6. (Optional) Select Enabled to enable DHCP.

    If you enable DHCP on a logical network and you have configured an on-premises DNS server, you must edit your compute gateway VPN to enable DNS queries to be correctly forwarded over the VPN by selecting cgw-dns-network as one of the local networks for VPN.

  7. Click OK.
messages.8c9c25e613fcceef9f17aab074171d86: The Summary page displays the current CPU, Memory, and Storage utilization of your SDDC. You can also add and remove hosts from your SDDC from this page.
messages.8e142af13e14fd0858db11652a4f6a91:
By default, there is no external access to the vCenter Server system in your SDDC. Open access to your vCenter Server system by:

  • Configuring a firewall rule to allow access to the vCenter Server system.
  • Configuring an IPsec VPN between your on-premises data center and your SDDC.

When you have configured one of these options, click the Connection Info tab to see how to connect to vCenter Server using the vSphere Client and PowerCLI.
messages.907e29f426a0e6cfe310ca3065113696: When you delete an SDDC, your VMs and data are deleted and the hosts and other resources allocated to the SDDC are released for use in other SDDCs. Back up or migrate off any essential data and VMs before deleting an SDDC.
messages.99a1f78f70ee152574b1f192a311da43: On the Dashboard, locate the card for the SDDC and click Actions > Delete SDDC.
messages.9a5c79ad338ec95353d9a47570c368bc: Yes. The user will be prompted to create a MyVMware account during the sign up process.
messages.9a876507c260d5e28f7888e94b34c30b:
By default, the firewall for the management gateway is set to deny all inbound and outbound traffic. Add additional firewall rules to allow you to reach vCenter Server and allow other traffic as needed.

  1. Go to the Network tab for the SDDC.
  2. Under either Management Gateway, expand the Firewall Rules section.
  3. Click Add Rule.
  4. Enter the rule parameters:
    • Rule Name: Enter a descriptive name for the rule.
    • Action: Only the Allow action is available for management gateway firewall rules.
    • Source: Enter one of the following:
      • an IP address, IP address range, or Any to allow traffic from that address or address range.
      • vCenter to allow traffic from your SDDC's vCenter Server.
      • ESXi Management Only to allow traffic from your SDDC's ESXi management.
    • Destination:Enter one of the following:
      • an IP address, IP address range, or Any to allow traffic to that address or address range.
      • vCenter to allow traffic to your SDDC's vCenter Server.
      • ESXi Management Only to allow traffic to your SDDC's ESXi management.
    • Service: Select one of the following:
      • Any (All Traffic)
      • HTTPS (TCP 443): applies only to vCenter Server as a destination.
      • Provisioning (TCP 902): applies only to ESXi Management as a destination.
      • Remote Console (TCP 903): applies only to ESXi Management as a destination.
      • ICMP (All ICMP)
    • Port: This is a non-editable parameter showing the port for the service selected.

Firewall rules are applied in order from top to bottom. Use the up and down arrow icons to move firewall rules
messages.9fee73eeba958dca24974ae6e88a6c55:
AWS Direct Connect is a service provided by AWS that allows you to create a high-speed, low-latency connection between your on-premises data center and AWS services.

Direct Connect is accessed through a private or public virtual interface. You can use a private virtual interface for ESXi management and vMotion traffic between your on-premises data center and your cloud SDDC. You can use a public virtual interface to access public AWS services and route management gateway IPsec VPN traffic over Direct Connect.

messages.ad24817552198eb1a923aebd467e0274:
After you create a VPN connection between the compute gateway of your SDDC and an on-premises compute network, you can verify that the VPN tunnel is successfully connected by looking at the VPN status on the Networking tab. VPN creation can fail due to misconfiguration of the SDDC or on-premises end of the network. Click VPN Status Detail for more information about VPN status, including channel and tunnel error messages. This list of VPN error messages includes suggested fixes for the root cause of the error.

Channel Message: Policy does not allow OAKLEY_RSA_SIG authentication...
Tunnel Message: No acceptable Oakley Transform, sending notification...
Suggested Fix: Set the on-premises VPN authentication mode to PSK.

Channel Message: peer is NATed...
Tunnel Message: peer is NATed...
Suggested Fix: Verify that the on-premises firewall opens port 4500 for UDP traffic between the on-premises VPN and the public IP of the SDDC VPN.

Channel Message: sending notification NO_PROPOSAL_CHOSEN ...
Tunnel Message: NO_PROPOSAL_CHOSEN ...
Suggested Fix: Download the SDDC VPN configuration and verify that the on-premises VPN has the same Phase 1 IPsec_configuration.

Channel Message: none
Tunnel Message: NO_PROPOSAL_CHOSEN msgid=00000000 ...
Suggested Fix: Download the SDDC VPN configuration and verify that the on-premises VPN has the same Phase 2 IPsec_configuration.

Channel Message: none
Tunnel Message: cannot respond to IPsec SA request because no connection is known for ...
Suggested Fix: Download the SDDC VPN configuration and verify that the on-premises VPN is reachable at the Local address shown under Local configuration addresses and the SDDC VPN UI shows that address for Remote Gateway IP.

Channel Message: initiating Main Mode, STATE_MAIN_I1: initiate, deleting state (STATE_MAIN_I1) ...
Tunnel Message: deleting state (STATE_MAIN_I1), STATE_MAIN_I1: initiate, initiating Main Mode ...
Suggested Fix:Verify that the on-premises management gateway firewall rules allow ICMP ping traffic to the SDDC VPN.

Channel Message: sending encrypted notification INVALID_ID_INFORMATION to ..., we require peer to have ID '208.91.1.25', but peer declares '10.146.97.30'...
Tunnel Message: sending encrypted notification INVALID_ID_INFORMATION to ..., deleting state (STATE_MAIN_R2), deleting state (STATE_QUICK_R2), Main mode peer ID is ID_IPV4_ADDR: '10.146.97.30' ...
Suggested Fix: The value configured in the SDDC IPsec VPN UI for Remote Gateway Public IP (208.91.1.25 in this example) does not match the value that the on-premises VPN is supplying for its identity (10.146.97.30 in this example). Edit the Remote Gateway Public IP value in the SDDC IPsec VPN UI or update the on-premises network to use a Local id that matches the Remote Gateway Public IP value in the SDDC IPsec VPN UI.

Channel Message: received 1 malformed payload notifies, ...
Tunnel Message: sending notification PAYLOAD_MALFORMED to ..., probable authentication failure (mismatch of preshared secrets?)...
Suggested Fix: Verify that pre-shared key configured for the on-premises end of the VPN matches the Pre-shared key configured in in the SDDC IPsec VPN UI.

For more information about troubleshooting VPN connection issues, see Troubleshooting Virtual Private Networks in the NSX for vSphere documentation.
messages.add-custom-service:
When you create a firewall rule, you can specify that it applies to network traffic from one or more of the services defined in your SDDC's Services inventory. The default list includes VMware services such as remote console and provisioning, standard services such as IKE, ICMP, and TCP, and many well-known third party services. You can add services to this list by selecting values, typically ports and protocols, from a list of service types and additional service properties.

  1. Click Services > ADD NEW SERVICE and give the new service a Name.
  2. Click Set Service Entries to open the Set Service Entries page.
  3. On the Set Service Entries page, click ADD NEW SERVICE ENTRY.
    To view the list of known services, use the drop-down controls to scroll through the Service Type and Additional Properties lists. To add a service, select a Service Type from the drop-down menu and specify Additional Properties such as Source or Destination Ports of the service, then click APPLY.
  4. (Optional) Provide a service Description and tag the service.
  5. Click SAVE to create the service definition.
messages.add-host: You can add a host if your SDDC contains fewer hosts than the maximum allowed. See Add Hosts.
messages.add-management-group:
Pre-defined management inventory groups are created automatically for SDDC infrastructure components such as vCenter and NSX Manager. You cannot modify a pre-defined management group, but you can create additional management inventory groups by specifying the CIDR blocks to which group members are connected.

  1. Click Inventory > Groups.
  2. On the Groups page, click MANAGEMENT GROUPS, then click ADD GROUP and give the group a Name and an optional Description.
  3. Click Set Members to open the Select Members page. Enter one or more IP addresses of management VMs in CIDR format.
  4. (Optional) Tag the group.
  5. Click SAVE to create the group.
messages.add-workload-groups:
Because compute inventory groups are made up of the compute VMs you deploy on your compute network segments. VMware Cloud on AWS cannot create them for you. You'll need to create them yourself before you can develop compute gateway firewall rules.

  1. Click Inventory > Groups.
  2. On the Groups page, click COMPUTE GROUPS, then click ADD GROUP and give the group a Name and an optional Description.
  3. Click Set Members to open the Select Members page. See Add or Modify a Compute Group for more information about ways to designate membership in a compute group.
  4. (Optional) Tag the group.
  5. Click SAVE to create the group.
messages.advanced-security: NSX Advanced Security for VMware Cloud on AWS gives your SDDC access to NSX application security features, including Context Profiles .
