messages.attach-private-vif: An AWS private virtual interface (VIF) uses a private IP address space and provides a private dedicated connection to the AWS network backbone, terminating at your VPC. Log in to the AWS console to create the private VIF, then log in to your SDDC console to attach the VIF. See Create a Private Virtual Interface for vMotion and ESXi Management Traffic. Note that your organization must accept responsibility for data transfer charges incurred for this interface before you can begin using it to connect an on-premises data center to your SDDC.
messages.available-roles:
An organization owner must assign each organization member one of the following roles:

  • Organization Owner: Only Organization Owners can invite other users to join the organization.
  • Organization Member: Organization Members can create, manage, and access cloud data centers belonging to the Organization, but cannot invite new users.

For more information, see Assign a VMC Service Role to an Organization Member.
messages.bb4bd2b0bac3cadb60ded3460a132c6c:
On the nextworking page, you can:

  • View a topology diagram showing the status of network connections to and from your SDDC.
  • Create firewall rules for the management and compute gateways.
  • Configure VPN settings for IPsec VPN connections between your SDDC and an on-premises data center.
  • Configure DNS settings for the management and compute gateways.
  • View logical networks. (To configure logical networks, use the vSphere Client.)
  • Configure inbound NAT for your compute gateway.
  • Create public IP addresses for your compute gateway.
  • View information about your connected Amazon VPC.
  • Attach AWS Direct Connect private virtual interfaces to your SDDC.
messages.bb6d9d33a0a0560a5eaa7ba985b8fceb:
Before you can connect using PowerCLI, you must create a firewall rule to allow access to vCenter Server. See Set Management Gateway Firewall Rules.

  1. Launch PowerCLI on your client machine.
  2. On the Connection Info page in the VMC Console, copy the command under PowerCLI Connect by clicking the copy button.
  3. Paste the command in the PowerCLI window.
  4. Replace the <password> with the password shown under Authentication.If the password contains special characters, enclose it in single quotes.
messages.c0ecc7ac8dc10d134d859bd7c95f90e0:
You can add a host if your SDDC contains fewer hosts than its maximum. If you don't see the Add Hosts option in the Actions menu, contact VMware.

To add a host:

  1. Go to the Summary tab for your SDDC.
  2. Select Actions > Add Hosts.
  3. Select the number of hosts to add.
  4. Click Add Hosts.

It might take up to a few minutes to resize the SDDC. While the hosts are being added, your workloads and vCenter Server continue to run as normal, but you are not able to start additional add or remove host actions.
messages.c1dcdcbe735c6e47a057611d5c3ed1f9:
Setting up an L2 VPN is part of the configuration of an extended network. An extended network has a single IP address space that spans your on-premises and SDDC environments. This simplifies migration of workload VMs to and from your cloud SDDC.

  1. Configure the L2 VPN Server in your SDDC. The Compute Gateway in your cloud SDDC acts as the L2 VPN server and provides the SDDC side of the L2 VPN that backs an extended network. Use the VMC Console to configure the server.
  2. Configure and enable your on-premises L2 VPN Client. After the SDDC side of the L2 VPN is configured, the system prompts you to configure the remote (on-premises) side of the L2 VPN. You can use your existing on-premises NSX for this, or you can download a standalone NSX appliance.
  3. Create an Extended Network in Your SDDC. Specify the IDs of the tunnels you created in Step 1 and Step 2. When the extended network has been configured, you can bring up the L2 VPN tunnel.

To verify that the L2 VPN tunnel is successfully connected, open the L2 VPNs row under Compute Gateway and refresh the Status.
messages.c4a6fedc7bfcfeb8f152266f21e8d145:
As part of the Management Gateway DNS settings, you must configure how to resolve the vCenter Server fully-qualified domain name.

  • If you access vCenter Server from the internet, select Public IP.
  • If you have configured a VPN and use the VPN to access vCenter Server, select Private IP.
messages.ccbad6ce65d351ae7236e3fd1697c46d:
You can request public IP addresses to assign to workload VMs to allow access to these VMs from the internet. VMware Cloud on AWS will provision the IP address from AWS. Before you you create a public IP address, you should assign your VM a static IP address from the logical network it is connected to.

  1. On the Network tab of your SDDC, click Public IPs under Compute Gateway.
  2. Click Request Public IP.
  3. Enter notes about this IP address and click Save.

To use this public IP address, do the following:

  • Configure a NAT rule to connect the public IP address to the internal IP address of a VM.
  • Add a compute gateway firewall rule to allow traffic between the public IP address and the logical network that the VM is attached to.
messages.choose-management-ip:
You can't change the values specified for the management network after the SDDC has been created. Consider the following when you choose these values:

  • Choose an IP address range that does not overlap with the AWS subnet you are connecting to. If you plan to connect your SDDC to an on-premises data center, the IP addresses you choose for the management network must be different from the ones in your on-premises data center, to avoid IP address conflicts.
  • CIDR blocks of size 16, 20, or 23 are supported. For CIDR blocks of size 20 or 23, the maximum number of hosts your SDDC can contain depends on the CIDR block size you specify and whether the SDDC occupies a single availability zone (AZ) or multiple AZs.
    CIDR block size 23
    Up to 27 hosts (single AZ). Up to 22 hosts (multi-AZ).
    CIDR block size 20 or 16
    Up to 160 hosts, regardless of number of AZs.
messages.compute-firewall-rules: The default Compute Gateway firewall rules block all inbound and outbound traffic. Before you can use a new Compute Gateway, you must create firewall rules that allow traffic as needed. See Set Compute Gateway Firewall Rules.
messages.compute-ipsec-vpn-connection: The Compute Gateway provides access to your workload VMs. An IPsec VPN provides connectivity between the Compute Gateway and the compute network in your SDDC. To create an IPsec VPN connection to the Compute Gateway, follow the steps in Create a Compute VPN .
messages.compute-ipsec-vpn-connection-err:
After you create a VPN connection between the compute gateway of your SDDC and an on-premises compute network, you can verify that the VPN tunnel is successfully connected by looking at the VPN status on the Networking tab. VPN creation can fail due to misconfiguration of the SDDC or on-premises end of the network. Click VPN Status Detail for more information about VPN status, including channel and tunnel error messages. This list of VPN error messages includes suggested fixes for the root cause of the error.

Channel Message: Policy does not allow OAKLEY_RSA_SIG authentication...
Tunnel Message: No acceptable Oakley Transform, sending notification...
Suggested Fix: Set the on-premises VPN authentication mode to PSK.

Channel Message: peer is NATed...
Tunnel Message: peer is NATed...
Suggested Fix: Verify that the on-premises firewall opens port 4500 for UDP traffic between the on-premises VPN and the public IP of the SDDC VPN.

Channel Message: sending notification NO_PROPOSAL_CHOSEN ...
Tunnel Message: NO_PROPOSAL_CHOSEN ...
Suggested Fix: Download the SDDC VPN configuration and verify that the on-premises VPN has the same Phase 1 IPsec_configuration.

Channel Message: none
Tunnel Message: NO_PROPOSAL_CHOSEN msgid=00000000 ...
Suggested Fix: Download the SDDC VPN configuration and verify that the on-premises VPN has the same Phase 2 IPsec_configuration.

Channel Message: none
Tunnel Message: cannot respond to IPsec SA request because no connection is known for ...
Suggested Fix: Download the SDDC VPN configuration and verify that the on-premises VPN is reachable at the Local address shown under Local configuration addresses and the SDDC VPN UI shows that address for Remote Gateway IP.

Channel Message: initiating Main Mode, STATE_MAIN_I1: initiate, deleting state (STATE_MAIN_I1) ...
Tunnel Message: deleting state (STATE_MAIN_I1), STATE_MAIN_I1: initiate, initiating Main Mode ...
Suggested Fix:Verify that the on-premises management gateway firewall rules allow ICMP ping traffic to the SDDC VPN.

Channel Message: sending encrypted notification INVALID_ID_INFORMATION to ..., we require peer to have ID '208.91.1.25', but peer declares '10.146.97.30'...
Tunnel Message: sending encrypted notification INVALID_ID_INFORMATION to ..., deleting state (STATE_MAIN_R2), deleting state (STATE_QUICK_R2), Main mode peer ID is ID_IPV4_ADDR: '10.146.97.30' ...
Suggested Fix: The value configured in the SDDC IPsec VPN UI for Remote Gateway Public IP (208.91.1.25 in this example) does not match the value that the on-premises VPN is supplying for its identity (10.146.97.30 in this example). Edit the Remote Gateway Public IP value in the SDDC IPsec VPN UI or update the on-premises network to use a Local id that matches the Remote Gateway Public IP value in the SDDC IPsec VPN UI.

Channel Message: received 1 malformed payload notifies, ...
Tunnel Message: sending notification PAYLOAD_MALFORMED to ..., probable authentication failure (mismatch of preshared secrets?)...
Suggested Fix: Verify that pre-shared key configured for the on-premises end of the VPN matches the Pre-shared key configured in in the SDDC IPsec VPN UI.

For more information about troubleshooting VPN connection issues, see Troubleshooting Virtual Private Networks in the NSX for vSphere documentation.
messages.compute-l2-vpn-connection:
The Compute Gateway uses an L2 VPN to provide access to workload VMs running in your SDDC. Setting up an L2 VPN is part of the configuration of an extended network. An extended network has a single IP address space that spans your on-premises and SDDC environments. This simplifies migration of workload VMs to and from your cloud SDDC. To create an L2VPN in an SDDC with networking backed by VMware NSX for vSphere, follow these steps:

  1. Configure the L2 VPN Server in your SDDC. The Compute Gateway in your cloud SDDC acts as the L2 VPN server and provides the SDDC side of the L2 VPN that backs an extended network. Use the VMC Console to configure the server.
  2. Configure and enable your on-premises L2 VPN Client. After the SDDC side of the L2 VPN is configured, the system prompts you to configure the remote (on-premises NSX) side of the L2 VPN. You can use your existing on-premises NSX for this, or you can download a standalone NSX appliance.
  3. Create an Extended Network in Your SDDC. Specify the IDs of the tunnels you created in Step 1 and Step 2. When the extended network has been configured, you can bring up the L2 VPN tunnel. To verify that the L2 VPN tunnel is successfully connected, open the L2 VPNs row under Compute Gateway and refresh the Status.
messages.configure-IPFIX:
IPFIX (Internet Protocol Flow Information Export) is a standard for the format and export of network flow information for troubleshooting, auditing, or collecting analytics information. You can configure flow monitoring on a logical segment. All the flows from the VMs connected to that logical segment are captured and sent to the IPFIX collector. The IPFIX collector can be in the on-premise data center on one of the logical segment.

Prerequisite

Verify that a logical segment is configured. See Create or Modify a Network Segment .

  1. Click IPFIX > COLLECTORS > ADD NEW COLLECTOR and give the collector a Name.
  2. Enter the collector IP address and port.
    The default UDP port is 4739. You can add up to four IPFIX collectors.
  3. Click SAVE.
  4. Click SWITCH IPFIX PROFILES to create or edit a switch IPFIX profile.
    See Configure Switch IPFIX Profiles for more information about NSX-T switch IPFIX profile parameters.
  5. (Optional) Tag the profile.
  6. Click�SAVE to create the profile.
messages.configure-nat:
Network Address Translation (NAT) maps internal IP addresses on your compute network to addresses exposed on the public Internet. To create a NAT rule, you provide the internal address and port number of a workload VM or service and a public IP address and port number that you have obtained from the system.

NAT rules have to run on the SDDC's internet interface, since that's where workload VM public addresses are exposed. Firewall rules, which examine packet sources and destinations, run on the Compute Gateway, and process traffic after it has been transformed by any applicable NAT rules. When you create a NAT rule, you can specify whether a VM's internal or external IP address and port number are exposed to firewall rules that affect network traffic to and from that VM.

  1. Click NAT > ADD NAT RULE and give the rule a Name.
  2. Enter the NAT rule parameters.
    See Create or Modify NAT Rules for details about NAT rule parameters and operation.
  3. (Optional) Toggle Logging to log rule actions.
  4. The new rule is enabled by default. Toggle Enable to disable it.
  5. Click�SAVE to create the rule.
messages.configure-portmirroring:
Port mirroring lets you replicate and redirect all of the traffic coming from a source. The mirrored traffic is sent encapsulated within a Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) tunnel to a collector so that all of the original packet information is preserved while traversing the network to a remote destination.

Port mirroring is used in the following scenarios:

  • Troubleshooting - Analyze the traffic to detect intrusion and debug and diagnose errors on a network.
  • Compliance and monitoring - Forward all of the monitored traffic to a network appliance for analysis and remediation.

Port mirroring includes a source group where the data is monitored and a destination group where the collected data is copied to. The source group membership criteria require VMs to be grouped based on the workload such as web group or application group. The destination group membership criteria require VMs to be grouped based on IP addresses.

Port mirroring has one enforcement point, where you can apply policy rules to your SDDC environment.

Prerequisite

Verify that workload groups with IP address and VM membership criteria are available.

  1. Click Port Mirroring > ADD PROFILE and give the profile a Name and an optional Description.
  2. Specify profile parameters.
    See Configure Port Mirroring for details about port mirroring parameters.
  3. Click SAVE to create the session.
  4. (Optional) Click the ellipses button next to a port mirroring session and select Edit to make configuration changes.
messages.configure-vcenter-fqdn:
You can connect to the SDDC vCenter Server at either a public or private IP address. A private IP address can be resolved from an SDDC VPN. A public IP address can be resolved from the Internet.

For more information, see Set vCenter Server FQDN Resolution Address.
messages.connect-powercli:
Before you can connect using PowerCLI, you must create a firewall rule to allow access to vCenter Server. See Add or Modify Management Gateway Firewall Rules.

  1. Launch PowerCLI on your client machine.
  2. On the Settings tab in the VMC Console, copy the command under PowerCLI Connect by clicking the copy button.
  3. Paste the command in the PowerCLI window.
  4. Replace the <password> with the password shown under Default vCenter User Account. If the password contains special characters, enclose it in single quotes.
messages.connect-vsphere-client:
Before you can access the vSphere Client, you must configure a VPN connection or firewall rule to permit access to vCenter Server. See Add or Modify Management Gateway Firewall Rules.

On the SDDC Details card, click OPEN VCENTER and use the Default vCenter Credentials to log in. To see these credentials, click SHOW CREDENTIALS on the OPEN VCENTER dialog. You can also find them under the Default vCenter User Account on the SDDC Settings tab.
messages.cpu-running-out: If you have the ability to add hosts, and your SDDC isn't at its maximum number of hosts, you can add a host to increase the available CPU capacity. Otherwise, shut down workloads or migrate them off of your SDDC.
messages.create-distributed-firewall-rule:
Distributed firewall rules apply at the VM level and control East-West traffic within the SDDC. All traffic attempting to pass through the distributed firewall is subjected to the rules in the order shown in the rules table, beginning at the top. A packet allowed by the first rule is passed on to the second rule, and so on through subsequent rules until the packet is dropped, rejected, or hits the default rule, which allows all traffic. Distributed firewall rules are grouped into policies. Policies are organized by category. Categories are just grouping conveniences and have no operational properties. See Add or Modify Distributed Firewall Rules for more information about distributed firewall rule categories.

  1. Click Networking & Security > Distributed Firewall.
    Click CATEGORY SPECIFIC RULES and select a category to view and modify policies and rules in that category, or click ALL RULES to view (but not modify) rules in all policies and categories.
  2. (Optional) Change the default connectivity strategy.
    By default, the Distributed Firewall includes an implicit Allow rule for all traffic. This rule, which does not appear in any list of rules, is evaluated after all other rules, and allows traffic that doesn't match a preceding rule to pass through the firewall. Click the connectivity strategy icon to see a list of available strategies. To change the current strategy, select a different one and click SAVE.
  3. To add a policy at the top of the list, click ADD POLICY and give the new policy a Name.
    To add a policy before or after an existing policy, click the vertical ellipsis button at the beginning of the policy row to open the policy settings menu, then click Add Policy Above or Add Policy Below. By default a new policy applies to the distributed firewall (DFW), but you can specify one or more inventory groups for it to apply to instead. The policy's APPLIED TO value is propagated to all the rules in the policy.
  4. To add a rule, select a policy, click ADD NEW RULE, and give the rule a Name.
  5. Enter the parameters for the new rule.
    Parameters are initialized to their default values (for example, All for Sources and Destinations). To edit a parameter, move the mouse cursor over the parameter value and click the pencil icon to open a parameter-specific editor. See Add or Modify Distributed Firewall Rules for more information about distributed firewall rule parameters.
  6. Click PUBLISH to create the rule.
messages.create-edge-compute-firewall:
By default, the Compute Gateway blocks traffic to all uplinks. Add Compute Gateway firewall rules to allow traffic as needed.

Compute Gateway firewall rules specify actions to take on network traffic from a specified source to a specified destination. Actions can be either allow (allow the traffic) or drop (drop all packets matching the specified source and destination). Sources and destinations can be chosen from a list of a physical network interfaces, or a generic specification of All Uplinks that refers to all traffic leaving the gateway and going to the VPC interface, Internet Interface, or Direct Connect interface. A firewall rule applied to All Uplinks does not apply to the VPN Tunnel Interface (VTI), which is a virtual interface and not a physical uplink. The VPN Tunnel Interface must be specified explicitly in the Applied To parameter of any firewall rule that manages workload VM communications over a route-based VPN. The Compute Gateway includes a Default VTI Rule that drops all traffic to the VTI. To enable workload VMs to communicate over the VTI, modify this rule or move it to a lower rank in the rule hierarchy, after more permissive rules.

All traffic attempting to pass through the firewall is subjected to the rules in the order shown in the rules table, beginning at the top. A packet allowed by the first rule is passed on to the second rule, and so on through subsequent rules until the packet is dropped, rejected, or hits the default rule, which allows all traffic.

  1. click Gateway Firewall to open the GATEWAY FIREWALL page.
  2. On the GATEWAY FIREWALL page, click Compute Gateway.
  3. To add a rule, click ADD RULE and give the new rule a Name.
  4. Enter the parameters for the new rule.
    Parameters are initialized to their default values (for example, Any for Sources and Destinations). To edit a parameter, move the mouse cursor over the parameter value and click the pencil icon to open a parameter-specific editor. See Add or Modify Compute Gateway Firewall Rules for more information about compute gateway firewall rule parameters.
  5. Click PUBLISH to create the rule.

See Add or Modify Compute Gateway Firewall Rules for more information about editing rule logging settings and viewing rule statistics.
messages.create-edge-management-firewall:
By default, the management gateway blocks traffic to all destinations from all sources. Add Management Gateway firewall rules to allow traffic as needed.

  1. Click Gateway Firewall to open the GATEWAY FIREWALL page.
  2. On the GATEWAY FIREWALL page, click Management Gateway.
  3. To add a rule, click ADD RULE and give the new rule a Name.
  4. Enter the parameters for the new rule.
    Parameters are initialized to their default values (for example, Any for Sources and Destinations). To edit a parameter, move the mouse cursor over the parameter value and click the pencil icon to open a parameter-specific editor. See Add or Modify Management Gateway Firewall Rules for more information about compute gateway firewall rule parameters.
  5. Click PUBLISH to create the rule.
    Firewall rules are applied in order from top to bottom. Because there is a default Drop rule at the bottom and the rules above are always Allow rules, management gateway firewall rule order has no impact on traffic flow.

See Add or Modify Management Gateway Firewall Rules for an example and more information about editing rule logging settings and viewing rule statistics.
messages.create-l2vpn:
A VMware Cloud on AWS extended network uses a Layer 2 Virtual Private Network (L2VPN) to extend an on-premises network to multiple VLAN based networks that can be extended with different tunnel IDs on the same L2VPN tunnel. This extended network is a single subnet with a single broadcast domain, so you can migrate VMs to and from your cloud SDDC without having to change their IP addresses.

  1. Click VPN > Layer 2.
  2. Click ADD VPN TUNNEL.
  3. Configure the VPN tunnel parameters.
    See Configure a Layer 2 VPN Tunnel in the SDDC for more information about tunnel parameters.
  4. (Optional) Tag the tunnel.
  5. Click SAVE to create the tunnel.
    Tunnel creation might take a few minutes. When the tunnel becomes available, its status changes to Up.

After the tunnel is up, you'll need to create a network segment bound to the tunnel ID of the new tunnel. See Configure Layer 2 VPN Extended Segment for more information about creating the segment and setting up the on-premises side of the VPN.
messages.create-logical-segment:
VMware Cloud on AWS supports three types of logical network segments:

  • A routed network segment (the default type) has connectivity to other logical networks in the SDDC and, through the SDDC firewall, to external networks. A Single Host Starter SDDC is created with a single routed network segment named sddc-cgw-network-1.
  • An extended network segment extends an existing L2VPN tunnel, providing a single IP address space that spans the SDDC and an on-premises network.
  • A disconnected network segment has no uplink, and provides an isolated network accessible only to VMs connected to it.
    1. To create a segment, click Segments > ADD SEGMENT and give the new segment a Name.
      To modify the configuration of an existing segment, click the ellipsis button an select Edit.
    2. Specify a segment Type and fill in the required configuration parameters.
      Parameter requirements depend on the segment type. See Create or Modify a Network Segment for more information about segment configuration parameters.
    3. Click SAVE to create or update the segment.
      This operation can take up to 15 seconds to complete. When the segment Status changes to Up the segment is ready for use. If the segment Status is Down, you can click the information icon to see status details.
messages.create-policy-based-vpn:
A policy-based VPN creates an IPsec tunnel and a policy that specifies how traffic uses it. When you use a policy-based VPN, you must update the routing tables on both ends of the network when new routes are added.

Policy-based VPNs in your VMware Cloud on AWS SDDC use an IPsec protocol to secure traffic. To create a policy-based VPN, you configure the local (SDDC) endpoint, then configure a matching remote (on-premises) endpoint. Because each policy-based VPN must create a new IPsec security association for each network, an administrator must update routing information on premises and in the SDDC whenever a new policy-based VPN is created. A policy-based VPN can be an appropriate choice when you have only a few networks on either end of the VPN, or if your on-premises network hardware does not support BGP (which is required for route-based VPNs).

  1. Click VPN > Policy Based.
  2. Click ADD VPN and give the new VPN a Name.
  3. Select a Local IP Address from the drop-down menu.
    If you have configured AWS Direct Connect for this SDDC and want the VPN to use it, select the private IP address. Note that VPN traffic over Direct Connect is limited to the default MTU of 1500 bytes even if the link supports a higher MTU. Specify a public IP address if you want the VPN to connect over the Internet.
  4. For Remote Public IP, enter the address of your on-premises VPN endpoint.
    See Create a Policy-Based VPN for important constraints on the remote and local IP values.
  5. (Optional) If your on-premises gateway is behind a NAT device, enter the gateway address as the Remote Private IP.
    This IP address must match the local identity (IKE ID) sent by the on-premises VPN gateway. If this field is empty, the Remote Public IP field is used to match the local identity of the on-premises VPN gateway.
  6. Specify the Remote Networks that this VPN can connect to.
    This list must include all networks defined as local by the on-premises VPN gateway. ​Enter each network in CIDR format. Separate multiple CIDR blocks with commas.
  7. Specify the Local Networks that this VPN can connect to.
    This list includes all routed compute networks in the SDDC, as well as the entire Management network and the appliance subnet (a subset of the Management network that includes vCenter and other management appliances, but not the ESXi hosts). It also includes the CGW DNS Network, a single IP address used to source requests forwarded by the CGW DNS service.
  8. Configure Advanced Tunnel Parameters.
    See Create a Policy-Based VPN for suggested parameter values.
  9. (Optional) Tag the VPN.
  10. Click SAVE.

The VPN creation process might take a few minutes. When the policy-based VPN becomes available, the tunnel status and BGP session state are displayed. The following actions are available to help you with troubleshooting and configuring the on-premises end of the VPN:

  • Click DOWNLOAD CONFIG to download a file that contains VPN configuration details. You can use these details to configure the on-premises end of this VPN.
  • Click VIEW STATISTICS to view packet traffic statistics for this VPN. See View VPN Tunnel Status and Statistics .
messages.create-public-vif: A public virtual interface (VIF) allows your SDDC to access AWS services that are external to your VPC, such as S3, over AWS Direct Connect. A public VIF uses a public IP address space and provides a private dedicated connection to the AWS network backbone, terminating in a specific AWS region. To create a public virtual interface in an SDDC, see Create a Public Virtual Interface for Access to AWS Services.
messages.create-route-based-vpn:
A route-based VPN creates an IPsec tunnel interface and routes traffic through it as dictated by the SDDC routing table. VMware Cloud on AWS uses the same public IP for all VPN connections, so only a single VPN connection (Route-based, Policy-based, or L2VPN) can be created to a given remote public IP. Route based VPNs in your VMware Cloud on AWS SDDC use an IPsec protocol to secure traffic and the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) to discover and propagate routes as new networks are created. To create a route-based VPN, you configure BGP information for the local (SDDC) and remote (on-premises) endpoints, then specify tunnel security parameters for the SDDC end of the tunnel.

  1. Click VPN > Route Based.
  2. (Optional) Change the default local Autonomous System Number (ASN).
    All route-based VPNs in the SDDC default to ASN 65000. If the remote ASN for any configured VPN connection also has this value, click EDIT LOCAL ASN, enter a new value in the range 64521 to 65535, and click APPLY.
  3. Select a Local IP Address from the drop-down menu.
    If you have configured AWS Direct Connect for this SDDC and want the VPN to use it, select the private IP address. Note that VPN traffic over Direct Connect is limited to the default MTU of 1500 bytes even if the link supports a higher MTU. Select the public IP address if you want the VPN to connect over Internet.
  4. For Remote Public IP, enter the address of your on-premises VPN endpoint.
    See Create a Route-Based VPN for important constraints on the remote and local IP values.
  5. For BGP Local IP/Prefix Length, enter the IP address, in CIDR format, of the local VPN tunnel.
  6. For BGP Remote IP, enter the BGP interface address of your on-premises VPN gateway.
  7. For BGP Remote ASN, enter the ASN of your on-premises VPN gateway.
  8. Configure Advanced Tunnel Parameters.
    See Create a Route-Based VPN for suggested parameter values.
  9. (Optional) Under Advanced BGP Parameters, enter a BGP Secret that matches the one used by the on-premises gateway.
  10. (Optional) Tag the VPN.
  11. Click SAVE.

The VPN creation process might take a few minutes. When the route-based VPN becomes available, the tunnel status and BGP session state are displayed. The following actions are available to help you with troubleshooting and configuring the on-premises end of the VPN:

  • Click DOWNLOAD CONFIG to download a file that contains VPN configuration details. You can use these details to configure the on-premises end of this VPN.
  • Click VIEW STATISTICS to view packet traffic statistics for this VPN. See View VPN Tunnel Status and Statistics .
  • Click VIEW ROUTES to open a display of routes advertised and learned by this VPN.
  • Click DOWNLOAD ROUTES to download a list of Advertised Routes or Learned Routes in CSV format.
messages.create-sddc:
To create an SDDC, pick an AWS region to host it, give the SDDC a name, and specify how many ESXi hosts you want the SDDC to contain. If you don't already have an AWS account, you can still create a starter configuration SDDC that contains a single ESXi host. There is a one-to-one relationship between SDDCs and customer AWS accounts. You can connect an SDDC to a single customer AWS account and Amazon VPC.

From the Dashboard, click Create SDDC to launch the Create Software-Defined Data Center (SDDC) wizard. See Deploy an SDDC from the VMC console for more information about this process. The status of the SDDC deployment is displayed on the Dashboard.
messages.delete-sddc: On the Dashboard, locate the card for the SDDC and click ACTIONS > Delete SDDC. Confirm that you understand the consequences of this action, which cannot be undone, then click DELETE SDDC.
messages.e1cba85551988a87c1139e690d5997ad:
Outbound Network Address Translation (NAT) is configured by default for the compute gateway. You can configure inbound NAT.

  1. On the Network tab of your SDDC, click NAT.
  2. Enter the NAT parameters:
    • Description: Enter a description for the NAT rule.
    • Public IP: Select the public IP address. For more information on how to provision a public IP address, search the help.
    • Service:Select one of the following:
      • Any: The rule applies to all traffic.
      • A specific service: The rule applies to traffic from the selected service and port.
      • ICMP (All): The rule applies to ICMP traffic, such as ping packets.
      • Custom TCP or Custom UDP: To define a custom service and port to apply the rule to.
    • Public Ports: If you selected a custom TCP or UDP service, enter the port or port range to route from.
    • Internal IP: Enter the internal IP address or block of IP addresses the public IP address should be routed to.
    • Internal Ports: If you selected a custom TCP or UDP service, enter the port or port range to route to.
messages.e87aff2a3ca94aca6476294af0962f5a:
On the Connection Info page, you can find hyperlinks for accessing the vSphere Client and vCenter Server for your SDDC. You can also see the initial password generated for the cloudadmin@vmc.local account, which you can use to authenticate to the vCenter Server.

If you change the password for the cloudadmin@vmc.local account, the password is not updated on this page.
messages.ef1277c930de7bd02f7937fb7b49d446: If you have the ability to add hosts, and your SDDC isn't at its maximum number of hosts, you can add a host to increase the available memory capacity. Otherwise, shut down workloads or migrate them off of your SDDC.
messages.ef936d7192ea7455d6def600da0c3062:
When you invite new users, you can assign them the following roles:

  • Organization Owner: Only Organization Owners can invite other users to the account.
  • Organization Member: Organization Members can create, manage, and access cloud data centers belonging to the Organization, but cannot invite new users.
messages.f162582a2057d3497784dd2a7579ba69: Currently, you can deploy an SDDC with a minimum of 4 hosts and a maximum of 16.
messages.f1744e41db8ba4a4ec281f5c63a3df29:
The default firewall rules for the Management Gateway and Compute Gateway block all inbound and outbound traffic. Before you can use these gateways, you must add firewall rules that allow traffic as needed.

  1. Go to the Network tab for the SDDC.
  2. To create a predefined set of firewall rules for the Management Gateway, expand Firewall Rule Accelerator under Management Gateway and click CREATE FIREWALL RULES to create rules in the selected Rule Group and VPN.
  3. To create firewall rules manually or edit rules created by the Firewall Rule Accelerator, expand Firewall Rules under Management Gateway or Compute Gateway.
  4. Click Add Rule.
  5. Enter the rule parameters:
    • Rule Name: Enter a name for the rule.
    • Action: Select Allow or Deny.
    • Source: Enter or select one of the following.
      • Select All Internet and VPN to apply the rule to all traffic from the Internet and VPN.
      • Select All Connected Amazon VPC to apply the rule to all traffic from the connected Amazon VPC.
      • Enter Any to apply the rule to traffic from all sources.
      • Enter one or more IP addresses or IP address ranges, separated by commas to apply the rule to traffic from those specific IP addresses.
    • Destination: Enter or select one of the following.
      • Select All Internet and VPN to apply the rule to all traffic to the Internet and VPN.
      • Select All Connected Amazon VPC to apply the rule to all traffic to the connected Amazon VPC.
      • Enter Any to apply the rule to traffic to all sources.
      • Enter one or more IP addresses or IP address ranges, separated by commas to apply the rule to traffic to those specific IP addresses.
    • Service:Select one of the following:
      • Any (All Traffic): The rule applies to all traffic.
      • A specific service: The rule applies to traffic from the selected service and port.
      • ICMP (All ICMP): The rule applies to all ICMP traffic
      • Custom TCP or Custom UDP: To define a custom service and port to apply the rule to.
    • Ports: If you selected a custom TCP or UDP service, enter the port number.

Firewall rules are applied in order from top to bottom. Use the up and down arrow icons to move firewall rules
messages.f44b2dc3154413e99b0427e8f9cd4d72: If you have the ability to add hosts, and your SDDC isn't at its maximum number of hosts, you can add a host to increase the available CPU capacity. Otherwise, shut down workloads or migrate them off of your SDDC.
messages.fe666a0d29b8c867ff39f4b94392a748:
When you deploy an SDDC using VMware Cloud on AWS, it is configured with two networks: a management network and a compute network.

The management network handles network traffic for the SDDC hosts, vCenter Server, NSX Manager, and other management functions.

The compute network handles network traffic for your workload VMs.
messages.firewall-rules:
You must create the following management gateway firewall rules to allow management and replication traffic required by the VMware Site Recovery service.

To enable management and API access:

  1. Allow inbound service HTTPS (TCP 443) to vCenter
  2. Allow inbound service SRM Server Management (TCP 9086) to Site Recovery Manager
  3. Allow inbound service VR Server Management (TCP 8043) to vSphere Replication
  4. Allow outbound service Any (All Traffic) from vCenter, Site Recovery Manager, and vSphere Replication

To enable replication traffic:

  1. Allow inbound service VM Replication (TCP 31031, 44046) to vSphere Replication
  2. Allow outbound service Any (All Traffic) from ESXi Management Only

To enable access to the Site Recovery console

  1. Allow inbound HTTPS (TCP 443) to vSphere Replication
messages.hcx: VMware HCX abstracts on-premises and cloud resources and presents them to workloads as a hybrid cloud. This allows workload mobility between your on-premises data center and cloud SDDC. HCX is included as part of your VMC on AWS service. For additional information on installing and configuring HCX, see the VMware HCX Documentation and the Hybrid Migration with HCX Checklist.
messages.how-dns:
You have to specify a DNS server on the management and compute gateways to allow hosts and VMs to resolve fully-qualified domain names (FQDNs) to IP addresses on the management and compute networks. See Set Management Gateway DNS and Set Compute Gateway DNS .

DNS must be configured separately for the management and compute gateways.
messages.how-invite-user: The organization owner can invite users to join the organization. Follow the steps in Invite a New User.
messages.how-remove-user:
To remove a user from an organization, you need to be an Organization Owner.

  1. From the VMC Console dashboard, click the services icon at the top right of the window, and select Identity and Access Management.
  2. Select the user or users you want to remove.
  3. Click Remove Users.
  4. Click Remove to confirm the removal.

The user is removed from the organization and will no longer be able to access the organization's resources.
messages.how-set-default-org:
If you are a member of more than one organization, you can set a default organization. This organization will be the one displayed when you log in.

  1. From the VMC Console dashboard, click your username and organization in the tool bar.
  2. Click Set Default Organization and select the organization you want as the default.
messages.how-switch-language:
To change the language displayed by VMware Cloud on AWS or any other VMware cloud service, set the language preference for your account.

  1. From the VMware Cloud Services console, click your username and organization in the tool bar and select My Account.
  2. Click Preferences.
  3. Edit the Language and Regional Format settings.
messages.invite-no-myvmware: Yes. The user will be prompted to create a MyVMware account during the sign up process.
messages.ipsec-vpn-connection: The Management Gateway provides access to the SDDC management infrastructure, including vCenter Server, NSX and ESXi hosts. An IPsec VPN provides Management Network connectivity between the Management Gateway and a network in your SDDC. To create an IPsec VPN connection, follow the steps in Use the Configure MGW VPN Wizard to Configure a Management VPN and Gateway.
messages.log-intelligence: VMware vRealize Log Insight Cloud enables you to collect and analyze logs generated in your SDDC. A trial version of the service is enabled by default in a new SDDC. A thirty-day trial period begins when a user in your organization accesses the service. After the trial period, you can choose to subscribe to this service or continue to use a subset of service features at no additional cost. For more information about using VMware vRealize Log Insight Cloud, see the vRealize Log Insight Cloud Documentation.
messages.logical-network: Logical networks provide network access to workload VMs. Your SDDC starts with a single default logical network, sddc-cgw-network-1. You can use the HTML5 vSphere Client to create additional logical networks. See Create or Modify a Network Segment.
messages.manage-vcenter-access:
By default, there is no external access to the vCenter Server system in your SDDC. Open access to your vCenter Server system by:

  • Configuring a firewall rule to allow access to the vCenter Server system.
  • Configuring an IPsec VPN between your on-premises data center and your SDDC.

When you have configured one of these options, click the Settings tab to see how to connect to vCenter Server using the vSphere Client and PowerCLI.
messages.management-compute-gateways: When you deploy an SDDC using VMware Cloud on AWS, it is configured with two networks: a management network and a compute network. The management network handles network traffic for the SDDC hosts, vCenter Server, NSX Manager, and other management functions. The compute network handles network traffic for your workload VMs.
messages.memory-running-out: If you have the ability to add hosts, and your SDDC isn't at its maximum number of hosts, you can add a host to increase the available memory capacity. Otherwise, shut down workloads or migrate them off of your SDDC.
messages.nat: Outbound Network Address Translation (NAT) is configured by default for the compute gateway. Inbound NAT allows you to map Internet traffic to a public-facing IP address and port to a private IP address and port inside your SDDC's compute network. To configure inbound NAT, see Configure NAT Settings .
messages.preshared-key: The pre-shared key is used by the two ends of the management gateway VPN tunnel to authenticate with each other, so both the SDDC gateway and your on-premises gateway must use the same key. The key has a maximum length of 128 characters. Treat the pre-shared key as you would a password: keep it confidential, and don't use email or other insecure methods to communicate the key to others.
messages.public-ip: If you have a workload VM that you need to access from the public Internet, request a public IP address for it. See Request or Release a Public IP Address .
messages.recommended-cryptography: The on-premises end of any IPsec VPN must be configured to match the settings you specified for the SDDC end of that VPN. See the IPsec VPN Settings Reference for information about available settings and recommended values.
messages.remove-host: You can remove a host from your SDDC as long as you don't go below the minimum required. See Remove Hosts .
messages.sddc-can-i-add-hosts: You can deploy additional hosts later if your SDDC contains fewer hosts than the maximum allocated to your organization.
messages.sddc-groups:
An SDDC deployment group connects your SDDCs and VPCs using VMware Transit Connect to provide high-bandwidth, low-latency connections between SDDCs in the group and to other VPCs in the same region. You can also add a Direct Connect Gateway (DXGW) to provide centralized connectivity to your on-premises SDDCs. An SDDC must meet several criteria to be eligible for group membership:

  • It must be owned by the organization that owns the group.
  • It must be in the same AWS region as other group members.
  • Its management network CIDR block cannot overlap the management CIDR block of any other group member.
  • It cannot be a member of another SDDC Deployment Group.
  • It must be at SDDC version 1.11 or later.

Peer connectivity among SDDC group members requires a VMware Managed Transit Gateway (VTGW). This is an AWS resource created by VMware Transit Connect and owned and managed by VMware. Adding the first member to an SDDC Group creates one of these resources and assigns it to the group. Creation and operation of a VTGW incurs additional charges on your VMware Cloud on AWS bill.

To create an SDDC Group:

  1. On the SDDC Groups tab, click ACTIONS and select Create SDDC Group.
  2. Give the group a Name and optional Description, then click NEXT.
  3. On the Membership grid, select the SDDCs to include as group members. When you have finished selecting members, click NEXT.
  4. Acknowledge that you understand and take responsibility for the costs you incur when you create an SDDC group, then click CREATE GROUP to create the SDDC Group and its VMware Managed Transit Gateway.

Charges begin when you click CREATE GROUP. You cannot pause or cancel the process after it starts. Group members won't be able to use VMware Transit Connect or its VTGW until deployment is complete. Deployment typically takes about fifteen minutes.
messages.sddc-how-many-hosts: A Single-host starter SDDC is limited to a single host until you scale up. Other SDDCs start with a minimum of two hosts and can scale up to a maximum of 16.
messages.set-compute-dns:
Your SDDC includes default DNS zones for the Management Gateway and Compute Gateway. Each zone includes a preconfigured DNS forwarding service. Use the DNS Services tab on the DNS Services page to disable, enable, or update some properties of DNS forwarding services for the default zones. To create additional DNS zones or configure additional properties of DNS forwarders in any zone, use the DNS Zones tab. See Add a DNS Zone for details.

  1. Click DNS .
  2. Click DNS Services to open the DNS Services tab.
    See Configure DNS Services for details about DNS service parameters.
  3. Click SAVE .
messages.srm: VMware Site Recovery allows you to perform automatic disaster recovery of virtual machines from your on-premises datacenter to your SDDC. For more information, see the VMware Site Recovery Documentation.
messages.storage-running-out: If you have the ability to add hosts, and your SDDC isn't at its maximum number of hosts, you can add a host to increase the available storage capacity. See Add Hosts. Otherwise, shut down workloads or migrate them off of your SDDC.
messages.undefined:
You can add a host if your SDDC contains fewer hosts than its maximum. If you don't see the Add Hosts option in the Actions menu, contact VMware.

To add a host:

  1. Go to the Summary tab for your SDDC.
  2. Select Actions > Add Hosts.
  3. Select the number of hosts to add.
  4. Click Add Hosts.

It might take up to a few minutes to resize the SDDC. While the hosts are being added, your workloads and vCenter Server continue to run as normal, but you are not able to start additional add or remove host actions.
messages.vms-cant-reach-internet: The default compute gateway firewall rules prevent all traffic from VMs from reaching the internet. To allow your virtual machines to reach the internet, you need to create a compute gateway firewall rule to allow outbound traffic on the logical network that your VM is connected to. See Add or Modify Compute Gateway Firewall Rules.
messages.what-can-i-do:
The VMware Cloud Launchpad is a consolidated starting point for all VMware hybrid cloud infrastructure and related solutions. You can use the links on this page to get started with migration solutions, explore VMware Tanzu Kubernetes Grid, or begin creating the infrastructure you need for the next steps in your journey to the cloud.

You can find more information about the Launchpad in VMware Docs.
messages.what-happens-when-i-delete:
When you delete an SDDC:

  • All workloads in the SDDC are terminated.
  • All data and configuration settings in the SDDC are deleted.
  • All UI and API access to the SDDC are terminated.
  • All public IP addresses for the SDDC are released.
  • All direct connect virtual interfaces in the SDDC are deleted.

Back up or migrate essential data and workload VMs before you delete an SDDC.
messages.what-is-connected-amazon-vpc:
During SDDC creation, you can connect your SDDC to an AWS account and select a VPC and subnet within that account. Using a CloudFormation template, VMware Cloud on AWS creates an AWS Elastic Network Interface (ENI), allowing your SDDC and services in the Amazon VPC and subnet in your AWS account to communicate without needing to route traffic through the internet gateway. You can only connect an SDDC to a single Amazon VPC.

You can view details of your connected Amazon VPC, such as the account ID, VPC ID, and subnet by clicking Connected VPC in the System category on the Networking & Security tab.
messages.what-is-direct-connect: AWS Direct Connect is a service provided by AWS that allows you to create a dedicated high-speed, low-latency network connection between your on-premises data center and an AWS Direct Connect location. You can access Direct Connect through a private virtual interface that you create in the AWS console. In an SDDC with networking backed by NSX-T, all Direct Connect traffic, including vMotion, management traffic, and compute gateway traffic, uses a private virtual interface.
messages.what-is-preview: Features released in preview have been released to gather feedback. These features are marked with a Preview icon in the UI. These features might not be available to all customers or in all AWS regions. We cannot guarantee that features that are in "Preview" will become available within any particular time frame or at all. Make your purchase decisions only on the basis of features that are available.
messages.what-is-traffic-group: In the default configuration, your SDDC network has a single edge router through which all North-South traffic flows. To provide additional bandwidth for a subset of this traffic, you can create one or more traffic groups, each of which creates an additional edge router, then create a list of CIDR blocks that you want to have routed through the new edge router. See Add Traffic Groups to Increase Edge Bandwidth for more information about creating and managing traffic groups.
messages.what-languages:
The VMware Cloud on AWS Console supports English, French, German, Japanese, Korean, Spanish, Simplified Chinese, and Traditional Chinese.

To change the language displayed by VMware Cloud on AWS or any other VMware cloud service, set the language preference for your account.

  1. From the VMware Cloud Services console, click your username and organization in the tool bar and select My Account.
  2. Click Preferences.
  3. Edit the Language and Regional Format settings.
